thread.title: Swimmers warned to avoid contaminated Wellington Harbour and Lyall Bay
thread.title_full: Swimmers warned to avoid contaminated Wellington Harbour and Lyall Bay

title: Swimmers warned to avoid contaminated Wellington Harbour and Lyall Bay
text:
Swimmers warned to avoid contaminated Wellington Harbour and Lyall Bay Last updated 15:58, February 3 2017 DAVID WHITE/FAIRFAX NZ 
There should be none of this at Wellington Harbour until Sunday, the council says, thanks to the heavy rain. 
The sheen of Wellington's first warm and sunny long weekend in recent memory has be stripped away by news the capital's harbour will be off limits for swimming due to contamination issues. 
Wellington City Council was advising people on Friday not to swim at Lyall Bay or in the harbour until Sunday after heavy rain on Thursday caused a small overflow at the Moa Point wastewater treatment plant near Lyall Bay. 
"Generally speaking 48 hours after heavy rainfall it's usually wise to avoid swimming in the harbour or swimming around the south coast," council spokesman Richard MacLean said. ROSS GIBLIN / FAIRFAX NZ 
Feed the seagulls, but don't swim at Lyall Bay this weekend due to a (heavily-diluted) code brown situation, the council warns. 
"We're not going to be physically stopping people getting into the water but the advice is, stay out." 
The overflow of heavily-diluted wastewater lasted less than five minutes but swimmers and surfers should avoid the water in the area until Sunday, the council said. Warning signs have been posted at Lyall Bay. 
People were also advised not to swim in Wellington Harbour until Sunday as pollution levels in the harbour will be higher due to contaminants washed down drains by the heavy rain.
